Electronic Music Performance                     Time: 45 hours Credits: 2 credits Term: Fall/Spring Instructor: Joel Chadabe, Dafna Naphtali    This course is about students working as an ensemble to create an improvisational performance based on field recordings and electronically generated or processed sounds. The performance, in a venue accessible to a New York public, will take place towards the end of the term. Depending upon the interests of the students enrolled in the course in a specific semester, professional musicians and multimedia artists may collaborate with the students in creating the performance.    Back to Course List                 Department of Music and Performing Arts Professions - 35 W. 4th Street, Suite 1077 -  New York, NY 10012 -  212 998 5424    This site, and all its contents, are Copyright ©    by New York University. All schedules are Live Google Docs    Undergraduate Course List    The following interactive table lists courses offered by the Undergraduate Music Technology Program. You can sort the results in the table according to row, by clicking on the corresponding header. For example, clicking the "Course" header will sort course names alphabetically. Clicking on the course name will take you to a description page for that course.    You can also listen to our podcasts describing the Music Technology program and several of the courses offered (you must have iTunes to listen). Issues and Strategies in Creating and Performing Electronic Music                     Credits: 3 points Terms: Spring Instructor: Morton Subotnick    Creating with New Media: students will create music with a technological medium of their choosing. The course will consist of lectures mixed with critiques of student presentations. The lectures will exam various issues and strategies in composing with new media and will focus on the Buchla 200e with tutoring as well as workshops to facilitate their learning the instrument. But, as stated above, the student creative projects will not be restricted to using the Buchla.
